guideline_title: 2023 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization
organization: American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association

recommendations.recommendation: Primary PCI is recommended for patients with STEMI presenting within 12 hours of symptom onset
Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor) for 12 months unless contraindicated
High-intensity statin therapy should be initiated in all patients with ACS
Beta-blocker therapy should be initiated within 24 hours in patients without contraindications

diagnostic_criteria: Chest pain or equivalent symptoms
ECG changes (ST elevation, new LBBB, or ST depression)
Elevated cardiac biomarkers (troponin)
Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium
treatment_protocol: Primary PCI if available within 90 minutes
Thrombolytic therapy if PCI not available

guideline_title: Surviving Sepsis Campaign: International Guidelines for Management of Sepsis and Septic Shock 2021

recommendations.recommendation: Administer antimicrobials within 1 hour of recognition of sepsis or septic shock
Obtain blood cultures before antimicrobial administration if possible
Administer 30mL/kg crystalloid for hypotension or lactate ≥4mmol/L
Use norepinephrine as first-line vasopressor

diagnostic_criteria: Suspected or confirmed infection
SOFA score ≥2 points
qSOFA score ≥2 points (systolic BP ≤100mmHg, respiratory rate ≥22/min, altered mental status)

guideline_title: Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes—2024

recommendations.recommendation: Metformin is the preferred initial pharmacologic agent for type 2 diabetes
HbA1c target <7% for most nonpregnant adults
SGLT2 inhibitors or GLP-1 receptor agonists with proven cardiovascular benefit in patients with established ASCVD
Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg

diagnostic_criteria: HbA1c ≥6.5%
Fasting plasma glucose ≥126 mg/dL
2-hour plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL during OGTT
Random plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL with symptoms
treatment_protocol: Add second agent if HbA1c not at target
Consider GLP-1 RA or SGLT2i for cardiovascular benefit
Insulin therapy if oral agents fail
Regular monitoring of HbA1c, blood pressure, lipids

guideline_title: 2017 ACC/AHA/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/AGS/APhA/ASH/ASPC/NMA/PCNA Guideline for the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Management of High Blood Pressure in Adults
organization: American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association

recommendations.recommendation: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg for most adults
ACE inhibitors or ARBs as first-line therapy for most patients
Thiazide-type diuretics as first-line therapy for most patients
Lifestyle modifications including DASH diet, sodium restriction, and regular exercise

diagnostic_criteria: Systolic BP ≥130 mmHg or diastolic BP ≥80 mmHg on multiple occasions
Proper measurement technique with appropriate cuff size
Multiple readings over time to confirm diagnosis
treatment_protocol: ACE inhibitor or ARB as first-line
Add calcium channel blocker if needed

organization: American Heart Association/American College of Cardiology

recommendations.recommendation: ACE inhibitors or ARBs for patients with HFrEF
Beta-blockers (carvedilol, metoprolol succinate, bisoprolol) for patients with HFrEF
SGLT2 inhibitors (dapagliflozin, empagliflozin) for patients with HFrEF
Aldosterone antagonists (spironolactone, eplerenone) for patients with HFrEF

diagnostic_criteria: Symptoms of heart failure (dyspnea, fatigue, edema)
Evidence of structural or functional cardiac abnormality
Elevated natriuretic peptides (BNP >100 pg/mL or NT-proBNP >300 pg/mL)
treatment_protocol: Lifestyle modifications (sodium restriction, fluid restriction, exercise)

guideline_title: 2021 Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke

recommendations.recommendation: IV alteplase within 4.5 hours of symptom onset for eligible patients
Mechanical thrombectomy within 24 hours for large vessel occlusion
Aspirin 325mg within 24-48 hours for most patients
Blood pressure management with target <185/110 mmHg for thrombolysis

diagnostic_criteria: Sudden onset of neurological deficit
CT scan to rule out hemorrhage
NIH Stroke Scale assessment
Time of symptom onset documentation
treatment_protocol: IV alteplase if eligible within 4.5 hours
Mechanical thrombectomy if large vessel occlusion
